home.description: PyCon Iran is a gathering for the community using and developing the open-source Python programming language. PyCon Iran is dedicated to advance its mission of growing the Iranian community of Python programmers.

events.news2: Discord server launched. Some parts of the conference are organized inside Discord. Please join the server
events.news3: The call for proposals is open and you can send your proposals until January 5
events.news4: The PyCon Iran Conference will be held from January 19 to January 21. You can register now
events.news5: The date of PyCon conference was changed. Iran PyCon will be held from February 16 to February 18
events.news6: The call for proposals extended to February 4

keySpeaker1.name: Trent McConaghy
keySpeaker1.title: Co-Founder of Ocean Protocol
keySpeaker1.about: He co-founded Ocean Protocol, building decentralized tools to level the playing field for AI and data. He has worked on AI since the mid 90s, Python since the early 2000s, and blockchain since 2013.
keySpeaker1.talkTitle: Title: Smart contract development with TokenSPICE & Brownie

keySpeaker2.name: Thierry Carrez
keySpeaker2.title: The Vice-President of Engineering at the Open Infrastructure Foundation
keySpeaker2.about: He is the Vice-President of Engineering at the Open Infrastructure Foundation. A systems engineer by trade, he was involved in the inception of the OpenStack project, and still contributes to its governance and release management.
keySpeaker2.talkTitle: Title: A Python-powered open source cloud: history and future of OpenStack

aboutPython.p1: One of the reasons Python is the friendliest and one of the easiest to learn programming languages, is the way people have contributed ideas to improve it. It can be done via the Python Enhancement Proposals or PEP. The most well-known ones are PEP 20 –The Zen of Python– and PEP 8 – Style Guide for Python Code.
aboutPython.p2: Long-time Pythoneer Tim Peters penned down the BDFL’s [Benevolent Dictator For Life] guiding principles for Python’s design into 20 aphorisms, only 19 of which have been written down:
aboutPython.p10: Special cases aren't special enough to break the rules.
aboutPython.p14: In the face of ambiguity, refuse the temptation to guess.
aboutPython.p15: There should be one-- and preferably only one --obvious way to do it.
aboutPython.p16: Although that way may not be obvious at first unless you're Dutch.
aboutPython.p18: Although never is often better than *right* now.
aboutPython.p19: If the implementation is hard to explain, it's a bad idea.
aboutPython.p20: If the implementation is easy to explain, it may be a good idea.
aboutPython.p21: Namespaces are one honking great idea -- let's do more of those!

about.p1: The year is half over, and most of it has passed in a blink of an eye. We have experienced many things together, fighting COVID-19 together, cheering for the athletes in the Tokyo Olympics and Wrestling World Cup, working hard for your future, and sharing your achievements with your family happily together.
about.p2: In the year that winter is coming, you must have a lot of gains, and you must also have a lot of questions. You must want to have an opportunity for you and like-minded friends in the community to get together and share your experiences with each other.
about.p3: So, PyCon Iran is here! We will bring you a wonderful online conference this year, let’s enjoy the joy and happiness that Python brings to us.
about.p4: PyCon Iran is a gathering for the community using and developing the open-source Python programming language. PyCon Iran is dedicated to advance its mission of growing the Iranian community of Python programmers.
about.p5: There is an old saying that “a conference is not a matter of one person, but a group of people,” so here we welcome everyone who loves the Python community to join us, participate in our work, and let’s make this year’s conference together a Dream Conference! Yes, we need you!
about.p6: PyCon Iran is a diverse conference dedicated to providing an effective experience to everyone. Help us ensure this.

aid.p2: is one of the most prestigious international conferences in the field of programming. The conference aims to bring together programmers using the Python programming language around a common theme, Python, annually in many countries.
aid.p3: We are glad that in our country, Iran, we have succeeded in obtaining the relevant permits from the organizing committee of the conference to hold the Iranian part of this conference, and more than that, we are happy to hold a Pythonic gathering with your presence.
aid.p4: You can help us to continue the conference at the best possible level by pressing the support button below.

becomeSpeaker.p1: We are very excited to be gathering online for PyCon Iran! PyCon Iran is seeking speakers of all experience levels and backgrounds to contribute to our conference program! If you use Python professionally, as a hobbyist, or are just excited about Python or programming and open source communities, we’d love to hear from you. All speakers will be presenting their topics online this year.
becomeSpeaker.p2: Everyone is encouraged to submit a proposal, regardless of experience level. We're looking for proposals on every aspect of Python: programming from novice to advanced levels, applications and frameworks, or how you have been involved in introducing Python into your organization.
becomeSpeaker.p3: Please also forward this Call for Proposals to anyone that you feel may be interested.
becomeSpeaker.p4: This is the conference structure for the online PyCon Iran 2021 taking place from February 16 to February 18
becomeSpeaker.p6: Thursday February 17: keynotes, talks, lightning talks, poster session
becomeSpeaker.p8: We will accept a broad range of presentations, from reports on academic and commercial projects to case studies. As long as the presentation is interesting and potentially useful to the Python community, it will be considered for inclusion in the program.
becomeSpeaker.p9: Can you show something new and useful? Can you show the attendees how to use a module? Explore a Python language feature? Package an application? If so, please consider submitting a talk.
becomeSpeaker.p10: There are multiple kinds of contributions that you can present at PyCon Iran; Before writing up a proposal, read the following descriptions of the five kinds of presentations at PyCon Iran — Talks, Tutorials / Workshops, Posters, Lightning Talks, and Sprints — and follow the individual guidelines for the proposal kind that best suits your topic.
becomeSpeaker.p11: These are standard “talks with slides”, allocated in slots of:
becomeSpeaker.p14: Most talks are 30 minutes long, but we do offer a limited number of 45-minute slots for important topics that promise to benefit from a more extensive treatment. Please choose a time slot you see most suitable to keep your presentation compact (so the audience can follow it without getting bored).
becomeSpeaker.p15: Hand-on, deep-dive into a subject with all details. Training attendees are encouraged to actively follow the training on their PCs/laptops. These sessions are approx. 3 hours long. As with the talks, we are looking for tutorials that can grow this community at any level. We aim for tutorials that will advance Python, advance this community, and shape the future.
becomeSpeaker.p16: Attention full-time trainers: Please bring your coursework to PyCon Iran. Educators can bring their show on the road, so show us what you have on the syllabus.
becomeSpeaker.p17: Posters are a graphical way to describe a project or a technology; posters will be online, can be read at any time by participants, and can be discussed with their authors during the poster session.
becomeSpeaker.p18: We are planning to collect all posters on a gallery page, together with PDF versions to read during the event.
becomeSpeaker.p19: A lightning talk (LT) is a short presentation which must not be longer than 5 minutes. You may talk about / present (almost) everything with certain boundaries:
becomeSpeaker.p20: no promotion for products of companies, no call for 'we are hiring' (but you may name your employer)
becomeSpeaker.p21: conference announcements are limited to one minute only
becomeSpeaker.p22: one LT per person per conference policy: everyone who has not given a LT at this year's conference, yet, is ahead of you in the queue
becomeSpeaker.p23: keep it short, the shorter the presentations, the more people can give a talk
becomeSpeaker.p24: For submitting sprints, please check our sprints page for more details.
becomeSpeaker.p25: Suggested topics for PyCon Iran presentations include, but are not limited to:
becomeSpeaker.p26: Core Python - Language Features, Python Implementations, Extending Python, Standard Library and extensions, and language internals.
becomeSpeaker.p27: Data Science, Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence (AI)
becomeSpeaker.p28: Programming Tools - CI/CD, Containers, Orchestration, Logging and Monitoring.
becomeSpeaker.p29: Game Design and 3D Modelling - Python in developing games, 3-D modelling and animation, Game Programming.
becomeSpeaker.p30: Scientific Computing - Python usage in scientific computing and research, GIS, Geophysics, Mathematics, Data-visualization and Simulations, Python powered data-acquisition systems etc. (core libraries e.g. Numpy, Scipy, and Matplotlib)
becomeSpeaker.p31: Decentralized and Distributed Technology - Blockchain, Tangle or any DLT protocol or infrastructure related product, cloud.
becomeSpeaker.p32: Desktop Applications - Qt, GTK+, Tkinter, Gnome, KDE, Accessibility.
becomeSpeaker.p54: Alternative Python implementations: e.g. Jython, IronPython, PyPy, and Stackless
becomeSpeaker.p55: Presentation goals are usually some of the following:
becomeSpeaker.p56: Introduce the audience to a new topic
becomeSpeaker.p57: Introduce the audience to new developments on a well-known topic
becomeSpeaker.p58: Show the audience real-world usage scenarios for a specific topic (case study)
becomeSpeaker.p59: Dig into advanced and relatively unknown details on a topic
becomeSpeaker.p60: Compare different solutions available on the market for a topic
becomeSpeaker.p61: Give a chance to less mainstream topics
becomeSpeaker.p62: Since the event will be run online, we ask speakers to make sure they have the following equipment ready on the conference days:
becomeSpeaker.p67: Because we’re using networks, we’d also like to ask for a few setups:
becomeSpeaker.p68: Send in a PDF with the talk slides, if possible
becomeSpeaker.p69: Chromium-based browser to use as a fallback streaming solution
becomeSpeaker.p70: You must pre-record the talk and then answer questions in the live session.
becomeSpeaker.p71: We recommend using Zoom for recording. It will be okay if you have other tools that can achieve the similar effect.
becomeSpeaker.p72: Please then upload the video to a web drive and send the link to us.
becomeSpeaker.p73: Part of PyCon Iran’s purpose is to generate materials to help with Python education all over the world, so we intend to record all PyCon Iran presentations and release the recordings on the web.
becomeSpeaker.p74: We also ask all speakers to:
becomeSpeaker.p75: accept the video recording of their presentation
becomeSpeaker.p76: upload their talk materials to the PyCon Iran website
becomeSpeaker.p77: allow the PyCon Iran to make the talk recordings and uploaded materials available under a CC BY-NC-SA license
becomeSpeaker.p78: To simplify the organization, we ask all speakers to accept the video recording and publishing of their session. All talks will be recorded.Talk slides will be made available on the PyCon Iran website. Talk video recordings will be uploaded to the PyCon Iran YouTube channel and other platforms.
becomeSpeaker.p79: As with all proposal types, we are really looking to you to talk about what’s going on in this community and tell everyone where it is going. If you are doing something awesome, share it!
becomeSpeaker.p80: Due to the competitive selection process, we encourage prospective speakers to submit their proposals as early as possible. For further questions and finally submitting your proposal, feel free to contact us via email, team@ir.pycon.org until Friday February 4.

becomeSponsor.p1: The PyconIr conference offers the following benefits in return for sponsor support:
becomeSponsor.p2: Placing the company name or brand on the front page of the conference
becomeSponsor.p3: Listed on the official schedule; Presenter pass not included
becomeSponsor.p4: One full-color slide will be displayed in rotation in general session & all breakout rooms in between talks.

table.r4c1: Logo in the PyCon Iran digital program guide
table.r8c1: Promo URL on the Virtual Swag page

buyTicket.p1: For this year, one type of ticket is considered, which includes the use of all conference facilities. Therefore, by purchasing this ticket, access to all online offerings and workshops will be provided.
buyTicket.p2: The cost of the ticket is 99 thousand tomans for each person
buyTicket.p3: To register and prepare the ticket, click on the button below to be referred to the Evand website to purchase a ticket.
buyTicket.p4: In case of any problems or questions in the ticket preparation process, please contact us through the Discord Conference channel or the conference email:

callForLogo.p2: Recommended to include some reference to the Python logo (2 snakes)
callForLogo.p3: Should work in small and large scale
callForLogo.p4: It must be in SVG format
callForLogo.p5: Think about how it'll be used on a screen-printed t-shirt. It should be able to be reduced to 1 or 2 colors, without fine detail.

codeOfConduct.p1: PyCon Iran is a community conference intended for networking and collaboration in the developer community.
codeOfConduct.p2: We value the participation of each member and believe in inclusivity, kindness, and a positive community for all.
codeOfConduct.p3: We expect all staff, attendees, speakers, exhibitors, organizers, sponsors and volunteers of PyCon Iran to conform to a professional and respectful manner at all times. This means:
codeOfConduct.p6: Respect others views  and experiences whether they do/don’t align with yours
codeOfConduct.p7: Show empathy towards other community members
codeOfConduct.p8: Be respectful of others in the public & private media
codeOfConduct.p11: Harass another person, whether publicly or privately in any form
codeOfConduct.p12: Use sexualized language or make unwelcome sexual/nonsexual advances
codeOfConduct.p13: Use another person's property whether physical or electronic, without their explicit permission
codeOfConduct.p14: Do any other actions that is inappropriate for a professional audience  including people of many different backgrounds
codeOfConduct.p15: Every member of our community has the right to have their identity respected. PyCon Iran is dedicated to providing a positive experience for everyone, regardless of age, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, ethnicity, nationality, race, or religion, education, location, technology choices, employment or socio-economic status.
codeOfConduct.p16: The Code of Conduct applies to interactions with official event accounts on social media spaces and phone applications, including:
codeOfConduct.p17: comments made on official conference phone apps
codeOfConduct.p18: comments made on event video hosting services
codeOfConduct.p19: comments made on the official event hashtag or panel hashtags
codeOfConduct.p20: Event organizers will enforce this code throughout the event.
codeOfConduct.p21: If a participant engages in harassing behavior, the conference organizers may take any action they deem appropriate, including warning the offender or expulsion from any private, online conference platforms, the community and community events with no refund of event tickets. Thank you for helping make this a welcoming, friendly community for everyone.
codeOfConduct.p22: We expect participants to follow these rules on all conference platforms.
codeOfConduct.p23: Language was incorporated from the following Codes of Conduct:
codeOfConduct.p24: PSF Code of Conduct by Python Software Foundation which is under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License.
codeOfConduct.p26: This Code of Conduct is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License.
codeOfConduct.p27: If you believe that someone is violating the code of conduct, or have any other concerns, please contact a member of the event stated below, immediately.

page.p1: It is possible to send job opportunities to be displayed in the job fair.

speaker1.name: Sepand Haghighi
speaker1.title: Master's degree in Computer Engineering from Sharif University of Technology
speaker1.about: Master's degree in Computer Engineering from Sharif University of Technology and Open source programmer, developer of art and PyCM libraries.

talkDetail.p1: ASCII Art is a type of graphic design that is produced using a computer and putting ASCII characters together. One of the applications of this method in the world of programming is to adorn programs including a command-line interface (CLI). The art library makes this possible in the Python programming language, and we'll cover that in this lightning talk.

speaker2.name: Yashar Shahinzadeh
speaker2.title: application layer bug hunter
speaker2.about: researcher and application layer bug hunter
speaker2.talkTitle: Title: A Security vulnerability in the Django framework

talkDetail.p1: The Django framework has a potential security vulnerability that becomes a dangerous one in certain circumstances. In this presentation, we will first define a series of concepts, then explain the Django security vulnerability, and finally show a live demo of the attack.

speaker3.name: Amir Mohammad Safari
speaker3.title: application layer bug hunter
speaker3.about: pupil and application layer bug hunter
speaker3.talkTitle: Title: A Security vulnerability in the Django framework

talkDetail.p1: The Django framework has a potential security vulnerability that becomes a dangerous one in certain circumstances. In this presentation, we will first define a series of concepts, then explain the Django security vulnerability, and finally show a live demo of the attack.

speaker4.name: Alireza Zolanvari
speaker4.title: PhD student in data science, University of Groningen
speaker4.about: PhD student in data science, University of Groningen and PyCM Library Developer
speaker4.talkTitle: Title: Post-processing of machine learning algorithms in Python

talkDetail.p1: One of the significant steps in machine learning is to evaluate the performance of the algorithm after achieving the results and outputs. To this end, many methods have been proposed, depending on the type of problem as well as the study data. The purpose of this presentation is to introduce and review strategies for evaluating the performance of machine learning algorithms and how to implement them in Python using the PyCM library.

speaker5.name: Sadra Sabouri
speaker5.title: BSc student at Sharif University of Technology
speaker5.about: BSc student in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Sharif University of Technology and Python Open Source Developer

talkDetail.p1: Generative Art refers to an art work that is generated in whole or in part by an autonomous system. We will create these generative arts through the use of Python programming language and Samila Library.

speaker6.name: Sebastiaan Zeeff
speaker6.title: Software Engineer for the Ordina Pythoneers and a Fellow of the Python Software Foundation
speaker6.about: Sebastiaan is a Software Engineer for the Ordina Pythoneers and a Fellow of the Python Software Foundation. As a Python enthusiast, he loves discussing the inner workings of the language and coaching others to become better developers. In 2021, Sebastiaan gave talks at various conferences, including PyCon, EuroPython, FOSDEM, PyCon Indonesia, Pyjamas, and PyGrunn. He is also active in the Python community, as an owner of Python Discord, an open-source contributor, and as a Python educator.

talkDetail.p1: Driven by the immense popularity of asynchronous frameworks, such as FastAPI, asynchronous database support suddenly became a hot topic in the Python community. As talking to your database often forms a significant portion of the input and output of your application, it's important to do that asynchronously as well. With the release of version 1.4, SQLAlchemy added support for Asynchronous I/O for both its core and ORM features. This means that you can now use the popular SQL toolkit for Python in your asynchronous applications.
talkDetail.p2: In my talk, I will introduce you to the newly added support for asyncio in SQLAlchemy. I will go over how easy it is to set up the new AsyncEngine, point you to some of the differences with synchronous SQLAlchemy, and show you some of the pitfalls to avoid. In addition, I will also show you how you can run your existing synchronous SQLAlchemy code asynchronously to help you transition to a fully asynchronous application. By the end of my talk, you should know enough to start your own asynchronous SQLAlchemy adventure.

speaker7.name: Soroush Mousapour
speaker7.title: CTO of Kayoosh academy
speaker7.about: Active in software development, analysis and development of various information security and reverse engineering tools with different programming languages, strongly opposed to object-oriented programming (except when using Django framework), believes in test-driven development, interested in periodic optimization! Soroush thinks that when a program is written, the optimization of the program (speed and resource consumption) and its proper functioning is more important than the tools and language in which the program is written, OOP and inheritance generally complicate the program, and Tensorflow is better than Pytorch!

talkDetail.p1: Are you also interested in how deep learning empowers intelligent applications? How do self-drivig cars, virtual assistants, face recognition devices, and chat bots process complex information? Whether you are familiar with machine learning or just starting out, this workshop will help you understand deep learning.
talkDetail.p2: In this workshop, we first investigate the relationship between machine learning, deep learning and artificial intelligence, and learn about the structure of the second version of Tensorflow. Next, we get to know the structure of neural networks and perceptrons, then we look at computer vision and get acquainted with convolutional neural networks, in the next step we go over text processing and use recursive neural networks, then we use GAN networks to create images. Finally, we examine the problem of implementing the model as a service and write various tests to review and implement it.

speaker8.name: Ahmad Fanaei
speaker8.title: Manager of Backend and Data team at Torob
speaker8.about: He started programming in high school with C ++ language and two-dimensional football simulation. He studied computer science at Sharif University of Technology. During his B.Sc, he became interested in the development of web-based software, especially Django. In 2014, he started a virtual reality project with a number of his friends in Sharif University of Technology’s accelerator, which unfortunately failed for some reasons, but he also got acquainted with Torob startup. Ahmed was hired by Torob Company in 2016 as a software engineer and is currently the Torob’s manager of Backend and Data team.
speaker8.talkTitle: Title: Performance improvement strategies for PostgreSQL database in Django

talkDetail.p1: Which tools can be used to find database performance problems in the development and production cycle of a Django application?

ul1.li3: Use squawk in the Deployment environment
ul1.li4: Use pg_stat_statment in the Production environment

talkDetail.p2: What are the serious performance issues of Django applications?

ul2.li1: Lack of proper use of select_related and prefetch_related
ul2.li2: Not restricting fields that must be returned from the database (the lack of only or values)
ul2.li3: Executing freezing migrations, such as adding new indexes to large tables
ul2.li5: Finding slow queries using pg_stat_statment and troubleshooting problems by checking the output of Explain command

speaker9.name: Hasan Noori
speaker9.title: CTO and co-founder of Formaloo
speaker9.about: Since 2016, as the Chief Technology Officer at Idearun Studio Startup, he has worked with many startup teams to develop their technical products and has been closely involved in the right and wrong methods of many novice startups to advance their technical products. Since starting Formaloo, as chief technology officer and software architect, he is engaged in the rapid advancement of a growing product. With a combination of technical and directorial background, he always strives to strike a balance between the technical ideals and the business facts of a startup.
speaker9.talkTitle: Title: Please stay away from microservices!

talkDetail.p1: In the world of technology, two things are relatively easy: following new trends, and rejecting new trends. But to do the right work in most cases, you have to choose a middle way. When and to what extent we should use new trends. To expand our services, we started a way that we could approach microservices step by step, but not in too big a step.

speaker10.name: David Tischler
speaker10.title: Developer Advocate at Balena
speaker10.about: David is a Developer Advocate at balena, where he helps show IoT Developers how to easily build and manage fleets of connected devices.  He spends time thinking about how technologies built for the cloud are now leaving the datacenter, and are instead being run at the Edge and on small IoT devices instead.  An Arm Innovator, obsessed with tiny computers and energy-efficient processing.
speaker10.talkTitle: Title: Scaling Python Apps at the Edge

talkDetail.p1: Python applications bring lots of flexibility and capability to IoT and Edge devices, but how do you deploy your Python code to devices that might be located across the country or across the world?  In this talk, we will demonstrate how to containerize your Python, then use balenaCloud to orchestrate pushing that container onto a device like a Raspberry Pi, no matter where it is located.  This same deployment method can be used across entire fleets of devices as well, saving developers’ time and effort when maintaining large fleets of IoT devices.  This talk will focus on constructing a small temperature sensor, but the concept presented can be replicated for any Python application.
talkDetail.p2: No hardware is needed to attend the workshop, but if you would like to follow along and build the project at home, then a Raspberry Pi, SD Card, and BME280 temperature sensor will be necessary.

speaker11.name: Gajendra Deshpande
speaker11.title: Assistant Professor, CSE at KLS.GIT
speaker11.about: Gajendra uses Python extensively for teaching and research, and is a well known speaker with a rich record, including talks at well known python conferences, such as PyData Global, EuroPython, PyCon India, SciPy India, PyCon FR, and JuliaCon. Gajendra uses Python to develop prototypes in the field of Cyber Security, and he leads the PyData and the OWASP developers’ communities in Belagavi, India. Gajendra loves to mentor and to volunteer at Free and Open Source events.
speaker11.talkTitle: Title: Security considerations in Python Packaging

talkDetail.p1: Popular programming language index websites (TIOBE index) and developer surveys (Stack Overflow) place Python as one of the fastest-growing programming languages. However, this popularity also puts in the target range of attackers. The attackers perform malicious dependency attacks and use misconfiguration tools to reveal confidential information. Jukka Ruohonen, Kalle Hjerppe, and Kalle Rindell in their research paper “A Large-Scale Security-Oriented Static Analysis of Python Packages in PyPI” claimed that they scanned PyPI for security issues in Python packages and found the presence of at least one security issue in about 46% of the Python packages. In addition, security vulnerabilities can be present in the source code of the package. In this talk, we will address the security issues related to python packaging and possible solutions to make python packages secure. The talk begins with the importance of a secure package and vulnerabilities in the Python package index. Then, I will discuss Python packages such as Bandit for identifying common security issues in Python code and “safety” for dependency check. Next, I will discuss verifying and signing Python packages using GPG and semgrep static analyser. Finally, I will discuss general guidelines for secure coding practices in Python.

ul1.li1: Importance of a secure package and vulnerabilities in python package index. (04 Minutes)
ul1.li2: Bandit for identifying common security issues in Python code (06 Minutes)
ul1.li4: Verifying and signing PyPI and conda packages using GPG and Twine (04 Minutes)
ul1.li6: General guidelines for secure coding practices in Python (04 Minutes)

speaker12.name: Parul Pandey
speaker12.title: Machine Learning Engineer at Weight & Biases
speaker12.about: Parul Pandey works as a Machine Learning Engineer at Weight & Biases. Prior to that, she was a Data Scientist at H2O.ai, where she combines data science and developer advocacy in her work. She is also a Kaggle Grandmaster in the notebooks category and was one of Linkedin’s Top Voice in the Software Development category in 2019. Parul has written multiple articles focused on Data Science and Software development for various publications and mentors, speaks, and delivers workshops on topics related to data science. Parul has a background in Electrical Engineering and was previously associated with Tata Power India.
speaker12.talkTitle: Title: An effort towards understanding our model's predictions

talkDetail.p1: Machine learning models are making predictions that affect people’s lives, so ensuring that they’re fair and unbiased must be an industry imperative. One way to ensure fairness is to discover a model’s mispredictions and analyze and fix the underlying causes. In this talk, we'll look at ways and try to understand the decisions of these models to ensure responsible machine learning. Additionally, we'll examine the vulnerabilities and shortcomings of these methods and discuss the road ahead. After all, it is not only enough to get accurate predictions but predictions that are fair and not discriminating.

keySpeaker1.name: Trent McConaghy
keySpeaker1.title: Co-Founder of Ocean Protocol
keySpeaker1.about: He co-founded Ocean Protocol, building decentralized tools to level the playing field for AI and data. He has worked on AI since the mid 90s, Python since the early 2000s, and blockchain since 2013.
keySpeaker1.talkTitle: Title: Smart contract development with TokenSPICE & Brownie

talkDetail.p1: This talk describes how to leverage Python and data science skills for design and verification of Solidity smart contracts for Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM). It will discuss how Brownie treats Solidity objects as Python objects, enabling more Python-based development flows. Then it describes how to use TokenSPICE to verify a contract via time-domain simulations involving many interacting agents, also in a Python data science oriented flow.

keySpeaker2.name: Thierry Carrez
keySpeaker2.title: The Vice-President of Engineering at the Open Infrastructure Foundation
keySpeaker2.about: Thierry Carrez is the Vice-President of Engineering at the Open Infrastructure Foundation. A systems engineer by trade, he was involved in the inception of the OpenStack project, and still contributes to its governance and release management. With a personal interest in the intersection of sociology and technology, Thierry spoke about open innovation and open source at various conferences around the world, including OSCON, LinuxCon, and FOSDEM. He currently serves as Secretary and Director for the Open Source Initiative. He was recognized as a Python Software Foundation fellow in 2012, and previously worked as the Technical lead for Ubuntu Server at Canonical, an operational manager for the Gentoo Linux Security Team, and an IT manager in various companies.
keySpeaker2.talkTitle: Title: A Python-powered open source cloud: history and future of OpenStack

talkDetail.p1: The OpenStack project was started in 2010 to create a ubiquitous, open source cloud computing solution. Twelve years later, where are we? Is OpenStack still relevant? What lessons do we have for Python and open source? In this keynote talk, we will look back at the history of the OpenStack project, present lessons learned, and discuss its future.

page.p1: PyconIr Conference is proud to have the support of the sponsors provided on this page.

sprints.p1: This year's Mentored Sprints will be run online through Zoom and Discord!
sprints.p2: This is a great chance to get to know open source or to promote your open source project.
sprints.p3: As is tradition, sprints are not organized by the conference organizers, but instead run by the attendees who want to put on a sprint. We only provide the virtual rooms and guidance on how to run the sprints.
sprints.p4: Most open source software development happens on the web and developers usually communicate online only when working on projects. This usually works out fine, but the lack of live meetings can sometimes be a limiting factor in making good progress.
sprints.p5: For this reason, a form of impromptu coding meetups called “sprints” or “hackathons” (outside the Python community, the term “hackathon” is more common) were initiated, where developers interested in a project can get together for a short period of time to make quick progress. Since conferences provide the perfect occasion to meet, sprints are made part of the conference program.

startups.t2: Does your startup qualify? Here are the criteria:
startups.p1: Startup Row is where early-stage companies go to show off what they’re doing with Python. At PyCon Iran, we reserve a special place for startup companies.
startups.p2: Startup Row gives early stage startups using Python a unique opportunity to connect with a motivated, highly technical crowd. Among the PyCon Iran attendees, could be a new co-founder, a startup's next investor, a future business partner, or even hundreds of new users.
startups.p3: You use Python somewhere in your tech or business stack (open source, proprietary, data science, machine learning, orchestration, marketing automation… it all counts)
startups.p4: Your startup is 3 years old, or less, at time of applying (if you had a major pivot or delayed product launch, measure from there)
startups.p5: You have 15 or fewer full-time employees, including founders, at the time of applying
startups.p6: PyCon Iran 2021 Startup Row applications are open!
startups.p7: Good luck! We look forward to reviewing your application.
startups.p8: Please submit applications by Friday February 4, 2022 via email (team@ir.pycon.org).
startups.p9: The technological landscape of tomorrow will be formed by companies like your startup. Therefore, do not hesitate to participate.
